articles.headline: Choosing Its Own Path, Ford Stayed Independent
articles.snippet: In what seemed like a desperate act three years ago, Alan R. Mulally’s decision to come up with private loans to stay afloat has proven to be its saving grace.
articles.abstract: In what seemed like a desperate act three years ago, Alan R. Mulally’s decision to come up with private loans to stay afloat has proven to be its saving grace.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — On Nov. 29, 2006, Ford Motor made a surprising pitch to the nation’s biggest banks. In a packed ballroom at a New York hotel, Ford’s chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, said he would mortgage all the company’s assets for billions of dollars in loans to finance an overhaul of the troubled automaker. Although the economy was healthy then, Mr. Mulally said the money would give Ford “a cushion to protect for a recession or other unexpected event.”

articles.headline: Obama to Push Immigration Bill as One Priority
articles.snippet: A senior administration official said the president planned to proceed, despite the political complications posed by the recession.
articles.abstract: A senior administration official said the president planned to proceed, despite the political complications posed by the recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: While acknowledging that the recession makes the political battle more difficult, President Obama plans to begin addressing the country’s immigration system this year, including looking for a path for illegal immigrants to become legal, a senior administration official said on Wednesday.

articles.headline: Standoff With Pirates Shows U.S. Power Has Limits
articles.snippet: Driven solely by economic gain, the band of pirates who captured an American merchant ship’s captain are an unconventional foe for the American military.
articles.abstract: Driven solely by economic gain, the band of pirates who captured an American merchant ship’s captain are an unconventional foe for the American military.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A U.S.-flagged container ship that was taken briefly by pirates in the Indian Ocean on Wednesday is headed to port in Mombasa, Kenya, and the F.B.I. has been called in to assist with the release of the ship’s captain, who is being held captive by four Somali pirates on a drifting lifeboat.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Sharon Otterman
